item.title: (Irving Kaplansky - Set Theory And Metric Spaces) Capítulo 2, exercício 2.3.5
item.description: Pergunta Let $A$ be a subset and $x$ a point in a metric space. Prove that $x$ is a limit point of $A$ if and only if there exist a sequence $\lbrace x_i \rbrace$ of elements of $A$ converging to $x$, with all $x_i \neq x$. Prove further that the $x_i$’s can be selected so that the numbers $D(x_i,x)$ decrease strictly monotonically, i.e., $$ D(x_1,x) > D(x_2,x) > D(x_3,x) > \cdots $$

item.title: (Irving Kaplansky - Set Theory And Metric Spaces) Capítulo 2, exercício 2.3.8
item.description: Pergunta Pove: The diameter of a set $A$ in a metric space is the same as the diameter of its closure. Solução Seja $A \subset M$. Como $A \in \overline{A}$ segue que $\text{diam}(A) \leq \text{diam}(\overline{A})$. Mostraremos então que $\text{diam}(\overline{A}) \leq \text{diam}(A)$. Sejam $x,y \in \overline{A}$.
